head.title: Reversibly Photoswitchable Catalysts for Olefin Metathesis Reactions | ACS Catalysis

meta.content: Reversibly Photoswitchable Catalysts for Olefin Metathesis Reactions

Azobenzene-bearing photoswitchable ruthenium catalysts were developed for olefin metathesis reactions. These catalysts exhibited an on–off switching ability in ring-closing metathesis depending on UV irradiation (>99% conversion without UV vs <1% with UV). Photoswitching phenomena have been observed in various types of olefin metathesis reactions, such as ring-opening metathesis, cross-metathesis, and ethenolysis. The photoswitching feature is also reversible, as the ring-closing metathesis reaction can repeatedly be turned on and off by switching the UV light source. Photoisomerization of azobenzene-bearing cyclic(alkyl)(amino)carbene (azo-CAAC) ligands and the corresponding ruthenium catalysts was observed by UV–vis spectroscopy.

div.p: Azobenzene-bearing photoswitchable ruthenium catalysts were developed for olefin metathesis reactions. These catalysts exhibited an on–off switching ability in ring-closing metathesis depending on UV irradiation (>99% conversion without UV vs <1% with UV). Photoswitching phenomena have been observed in various types of olefin metathesis reactions, such as ring-opening metathesis, cross-metathesis, and ethenolysis. The photoswitching feature is also reversible, as the ring-closing metathesis reaction can repeatedly be turned on and off by switching the UV light source. Photoisomerization of azobenzene-bearing cyclic(alkyl)(amino)carbene (azo-CAAC) ligands and the corresponding ruthenium catalysts was observed by UV–vis spectroscopy.

Switchable catalysts can control the reaction rate and/or chemo-, regio-, and stereoselectivity of a reaction in response to external stimuli.
(1)
Switchable catalysts typically have a stimulus-responsive structure that allows changes in their electronic or steric properties to achieve the desired results in a catalytic reaction. With much interest in olefin metathesis reactions, various stimulus-responsive (i.e., acid-,
(2)
heat-,
(3)
ultrasound-,
(4)
and redox-switchable
(5)
) metathesis catalysts have been developed. Light is an attractive stimulus, as it is noninvasive and can conveniently be manipulated with high temporal and spatial resolution. Therefore, a number of photoswitchable metathesis catalysts have been disclosed.
(6)
The reported photoresponse mechanism of olefin metathesis catalysts includes activating dormant catalysts by light energy or tuning the electronic properties of the ligands upon photoisomerization (
Figure 1
).

Figure 1. Representative photoswitchable olefin metathesis catalysts. (a) Ru–S dissociation.
(6a−f)
(b) Ru-Ligand dissociation with photocatalyst.
(6g)
(c) Electrocyclication of dithienylethene.
(6h)

Azobenzene is a photochromic compound that can be photoisomerized (
trans
–
cis
) reversibly, resulting in structural changes. The photochromic properties of azobenzene have been utilized in a variety of polymers, protein probes, and molecular machines.
(7)
However, the photoisomerization capabilities of azobenzene in transition-metal catalysts have rarely been explored.
(8)
We envisioned that introducing an azobenzene functionality in the metathesis catalyst ligand could lead to the novel photoswitchable metathesis catalysts whose ligand structure can reversibly be changed by light. Herein, we report photoswitchable, azobenzene-functionalized cyclic(alkyl)(amino)carbene-ruthenium (
CAAC-Ru
) catalysts whose olefin metathesis reactivity can be reversibly toggled depending upon light irradiation.

Ring-closing metathesis (RCM) reactions were conducted with the newly synthesized photoswitchable catalyst
Ru1
under dark, ambient laboratory light, or ultraviolet irradiation conditions (
Table 1
). Without UV irradiation,
Ru1
efficiently catalyzed the RCM of diethyl diallyl malonate, showing >99% conversion (entries 1 and 2). In contrast, with UV irradiation, the RCM reaction did not proceed with
Ru1
(<1% conversion, entry 3). Thus,
Ru1
exhibited totally different reactivity for the RCM reaction of diethyl diallyl malonate depending on the presence of UV light. Furthermore, while the RCM reaction did not proceed with UV irradiation, removing the UV light allowed the RCM reaction to proceed, showing >99% conversion (entry 4). It is noteworthy that the reactivity of the
Ru1
is not only significantly different depending on the light conditions but also switchable. For the control experiments,
CAAC-Ru
, which has a phenyl group in lieu of the azobenzene group in
Ru1
, was prepared according to the reported procedures. When the RCM reaction was catalyzed by
CAAC-Ru
under the same reaction conditions used for
Ru1
, full conversion was achieved, regardless of the light conditions (entries 5 and 6). Therefore, the azobenzene group of the
Ru1
catalyst could play a pivotal role in promoting switchable reactivity in the RCM reaction depending on the UV light conditions.

div.div:
Table 1. RCM Reactions Catalyzed by
Ru1
and
CAAC-Ru
Depending on the Light Conditions

div.p:
Determined by
1
H NMR spectroscopy.

With the newly synthesized azobenzene-bearing CAAC-Ru catalysts
Ru1
(N-aryl = 2,5-diisopropylphenyl) and
Ru2
(N-aryl = 2,5-diethylphenyl), the scope of photoswitching catalysis was investigated in various metathesis reactions (
Table 2
). Without UV irradiation, RCM reactions of di- and trisubstituted malonate (
1
and
3
) proceeded with excellent conversions. In contrast, under UV irradiation, the same catalyst showed almost no conversion for RCM reactions of
1
and
3
(entries 1 and 2). Ring-opening metathesis polymerization (ROMP) reactions of cyclic olefins (
5
,
7
) and norbornene (
9
) catalyzed by
Ru1
and
Ru2
showed good to excellent conversions under dark conditions. In contrast, UV irradiation turned off the ROMP of
5
,
7
, and
9
, resulting in low or poor conversion (entries 3, 4, and 5). While ethenolysis (cross-metathesis with ethylene) of methyl oleate (
11
) proceeded smoothly (76% conversion) under dark conditions, UV irradiation almost completely turned off the ethenolysis (entry 6). A similar trend was observed with cross-metathesis of terminal alkenes (
13
and
15
), where UV irradiation turned off the cross-metathesis catalytic activity (entries 7 and 8). As summarized in
Table 2
and
Figure 2
, azobenzene-bearing
CAAC-Ru
catalysts (
Ru1
and
Ru2
) exhibited striking on/off photoswitching phenomena in various metathesis reactions, such as RCM, ROMP, cross-metathesis, and ethenolysis.

div.div: Table 2. Scope of Photoswitching Catalysis in Various Metathesis Reactions

div.p: Figure 2. Photoswitching phenomena in various metathesis reactions.

We then were wondering whether the photoswitching phenomena could be reversible. Thus, the
Ru1
-catalyzed RCM reaction of diethyl diallyl maloate was monitored under continuously changing light conditions (
Figure 3
). During the UV irradiation period,
Ru1
showed no reactivity for RCM. However, the removal of UV light and exposure to visible light turned the catalytic activity of
Ru1
toward the RCM reaction back on. As the light conditions continued to change, the reactivity of the catalyst switched accordingly, indicating that the catalytic activity can be reversibly switched by UV light. It is worthwhile noting that the azobenzene-bearing
CAAC-Ru
catalysts turn off the metathesis reactions by illuminating UV light,
(9)
while a number of photocontrolled catalysts show the opposite behavior.
(10)
Potential benefits of this photodeactivating switchable catalyst system include opposite results in photolithography.
(11)
Furthermore, one can design an interesting cooperative catalyst system consisting of photodeactivating catalysts and photoactivating catalysts. For example, switching light conditions can selectively turn on one of those complementary catalysts (a photoinitiating reaction occurs while the photodeactivating catalysts are dormant with the light on, and vice versa).
(12)

Figure 3. Ring-closing metathesis catalyzed by
Ru1
under conditions of switching light irradiation.

The newly synthesized ligand (
AzoCAAC1
) and the corresponding ruthenium catalyst
Ru1
were characterized by UV–vis spectroscopy (
Figure 4
). A solution of the
Azo-CAAC1
ligand in acetonitrile displays intense π–π* band absorption at 322 nm in the UV–vis spectrum (
Figure 4
a).

Figure 4. UV–vis spectroscopic data of the (a)
AzoCAAC1
ligand, (b)
Ru1
catalyst.

Photoisomerization was investigated by irradiating a solution of the
AzoCAAC1
ligand with UV light. Irradiation of the ligand solution with UV light for a few minutes resulted in a decrease in the π–π* transition band at 322 nm and a slight increase in the n-π* transition band at 426 nm in the UV–vis spectrum. After UV irradiation and subsequent irradiation with visible light, the UV–vis spectrum showed absorption bands similar to those of the initial
AzoCAAC1
. The change in the UV–vis absorption spectra of the
AzoCAAC1
ligand indicates that
AzoCAAC1
has photochromic properties similar to those of other reported azobenzene-bearing molecules.
(13)
As shown in
Figure 4
, the
Ru1
complex also showed photoisomerization behavior similar to that of the ligand.

The UV–vis spectrum of
Ru1
showed intense π–π* band absorption at 330 nm in the UV–vis spectrum. Irradiation with UV light for a few minutes resulted in a decrease in the π–π* transition band at 330 nm and a slight increase in the n−π* transition band at 430 nm. The absorption band of
Ru1
at 386 nm can be ascribed to metal–ligand charge transfer, as also observed in the UV–vis spectrum of
CAAC-Ru
(see Figure S32 in the
Supporting Information
). After UV irradiation and subsequent irradiation with visible light, the UV–vis spectrum showed absorption bands similar to those of the initial
Ru1
. Therefore, the UV–vis spectroscopy study revealed that both the ligand and the catalyst can undergo reversible photoisomerization. Furthermore, these results also suggest that the origin of the photoswitching property of the catalysts (
Ru1
and
Ru2
) can be attributed to the photoisomerization of the azobenzene group. The
cis
/
trans
equilibrium ratio of azobenzenes is typically 90:10.
(14)
The
1
H NMR studies indicate that the cis/trans ratio of photostationary state of
Ru1
might be far from >99:1 (See
Supporting Information
for details), which is puzzling to explain the observed switching phenomena. Thus it seems that somehow the generation of the
cis
can inhibit the metathesis reaction, even if there is still the
trans
remaining.

The electronic properties of ligands can significantly affect the reactivity of organometallic catalysts. Electronic properties of a ligand can often be evaluated by the Tolman electronic parameter (TEP) of metal–carbonyl complexes. A rhodium–carbonyl complex (
Rh1
) bearing
AzoCAAC1
was prepared to determine whether the reversible photoswitching property of the catalyst originates from changes in the electronic properties of the ligand upon photoisomerization of the azobenzene group. The CO vibrational frequency of of
trans
Rh1
was measured by FT-IR spectroscopy. The TEP value of
trans
Rh1
was 2051 cm
–1
, which was calculated from the carbonyl stretching frequencies of 2079 and 1998 cm
–1
. Additionally, by means of UV–vis spectroscopy, we identified that
Rh1
can be photoisomerized under UV light (see Figure S28 in the
Supporting Information
). To obtain the TEP value of
cis
Rh1
, the CO vibrational frequency of UV-irradiated
Rh1
was measured by FT-IR spectroscopy. The TEP value of
cis
Rh1
was 2051 cm
–1
, as determined from the carbonyl stretching frequencies of 2079 and 1998 cm
–1
, which is identical to that the value of
trans
Rh1
. Thus, we can conclude that reactivity differences between
trans
Ru
and
cis
Ru
are not a result of changes in the electronic properties of the carbene ligand.

The steric bulk of ligands on ruthenium metathesis catalysts is an important factor that determines the reactivity, selectivity, and stability of the catalysts. To investigate the change in steric hindrance induced by photoisomerization of azobenzene at
Ru1
, the
trans
and
cis
geometry of the
Ru1
methylidene complex structure were optimized by DFT calculations using Gaussian 09 at the B3LYP/6-31G(d,p) level; LanL2DZ[Ru] of the
DFT
trans
Ru1
complex and
DFT
cis
Ru1
were obtained (
Figure 5
b). The topographic steric map and % buried volume (%V
Bur
) of the optimized structure
DFT
trans
Ru1
and
DFT
cis
Ru1
were calculated by SambVca2. As seen by comparing the quadrantal %V
Bur
of
DFT
trans
Ru1
and
DFT
cis
Ru1
, the east-side values, which represent the N-aryl group part of
Ru1
, are similar (45.6% and 45.5%, respectively). However, on the northwest side, the %V
Bur
of
DFT
cis
Ru1
is significantly higher than the %V
Bur
of
DFT
trans
Ru1
(52.4% and 41.6%, respectively), which results from photoisomerization of azobenzene. The total %V
Bur
of
DFT
cis
Ru1
was larger than that of
DFT
tran
s
Ru1
(42.4% and 45.0%, respectively). Through a computational study, it is suggested that
Ru1
has different steric bulk depending on the light.

Figure 5. Optimized calculated structures of (a)
trans
and (b)
cis
forms of
Ru1
. Topographic steric maps of (c)
DFT
trans
Ru1
and (d)
DFT
cis
Ru1
with quadrantal %V
Bur
values.

In conclusion, we have developed ruthenium metathesis catalysts whose reactivity can be switched by photoisomerization of azobenzene with light. The photoswitchable ruthenium catalysts exhibited moderate to excellent activity in various metathesis reactions, such as RCM, ROMP, cross metathesis, and ethenolysis, whereas upon UV irradiation, all metathesis reactions were totally decelerated. Additionally, through RCM reactions controlled by switching light stimulation, we observed that the reactivity of the catalyst can be reversibly switched by controlling the light conditions. Photoisomerization of the
AzoCAAC1
ligand and
Ru1
catalyst was observed via UV–vis spectroscopy analysis. There was no significant change in electronic properties, but the structure and the steric bulk of the ligand seemed to be changed. However, the imperfect
cis/trans
equilibrium ratio implies that somehow the generation of the
cis
form can inhibit the metathesis reaction, even if there is still the
trans
form remaining. Currently, further mechanistic study is ongoing in our laboratory and the results will be reported in due course.

The Supporting Information is available free of charge at
https://pubs.acs.org/doi/10.1021/acscatal.1c04281
.

A review. Catalysis is key to the effective and efficient transformation of readily available building blocks into high value functional mols. and materials. For many years research in this field has largely focused on the invention of new catalysts and the optimization of their performance to achieve high conversions and/or selectivities. However, inspired by Nature, chemists are beginning to turn their attention to the development of catalysts whose activity in different chem. processes can be switched by an external stimulus. Potential applications include using the states of multiple switchable catalysts to control sequences of transformations, producing different products from a pool of building blocks according to the order and type of stimuli applied. Here we outline the state-of-art in artificial switchable catalysis, classifying systems according to the trigger used to achieve control over the catalytic activity and stereochem. or other structural outcomes of the reaction.

A review. Synthetic polymer chem. endeavors to imitate the spatial and temporal control exhibited within biol. systems to obtain well-defined polymeric materials with unique structures, properties, and applications. This is often approached through the development of dynamic catalyst (or initiator) systems that use external stimuli to elicit discrete, site specific transformations that impact the polymn. Herein, we highlight developments in polymns. that are modulated by external stimuli, with particular focus on those systems that enable notable changes in kinetics, monomer selectivity, polymer architecture, or tacticity. Examples of external stimuli include chem. oxidants or reductants, light, applied voltage, and mech. force.

It is well-recognized that N-heterocyclic carbene (NHC) ligands have provided a new dimension to the design of homogeneous catalysts. Part of the success of this type of ligands resides in the limitless access to a variety of topologies with tuned electronic properties, but also in the ability of a family of NHCs that are able to adapt their properties to the specific requirements of individual catalytic transformations. The term "smart" is used here to refer to switchable, multifunctional, adaptable, or tunable ligands and, in general, to all those ligands that are able to modify their steric or electronic properties to fulfill the requirements of a defined catalytic reaction. The purpose of this review is to comprehensively describe all types of smart NHC ligands by focusing attention on the catalytically relevant ligand-based reactivity.

A review. While significant progress has clearly been made,future efforts should be directed toward achieving more sophisticated control over the switchable characteristics of a system. For instance, the synthesis of complex materials with precisely tailored microstructures may be possible through the development of polymn. catalyst capable of two discrete switching mechanisms induced by orthogonal external stimuli. Alternatively, the development of novel switchable polymn. catalysts contg. multiple distinct catalytic center that can be selectively switched on and off independent of each other could also lead to an enhanced level of control over polymer architecture (e.g., tacticity, compn., topol., etc.). Nevertheless, the nascent field of switchable polymns. represents a useful alternative to conventional methods and is expected to facilitate the realization of new polymeric materials that are currently challenging or impossible to synthesize using known techniques.

A review is given. Responsive systems have recently gained much interest in the scientific community in attempts to mimic dynamic functions in biol. systems. One of the fascinating potential applications of responsive systems lies in catalysis. Inspired by nature, novel responsive catalytic systems have been built that show analogy with allosteric regulation of enzymes. The design of responsive catalytic systems allows control of catalytic activity and selectivity. Here, advances in the field over the last 4 decades are discussed and a comparison is made amongst the dynamic responsive systems based on the principles underlying their catalytic mechanisms. The catalyst systems are sorted according to the triggers used to achieve control of the catalytic activity and the distinct catalytic reactions illustrated.

Grubbs-Hoveyda and Grubbs III type complexes with ferrocenyl- or -NEt2-substituted NHC ligands were synthesized according to std. procedures. The electron donation of the NHC ligands in the resp. Ru complexes can be modulated by oxidn. of the ferrocenyl moiety or by protonation of the amino group. The neutral and the resp. cationic (oxidized or protonated) Ru complexes were tested in the ROMP of norbornene. The change in the electron donation of the NHC ligands upon protonation leads to a significant change in the double-bond geometry (from E/Z ratio = 0.78 to E/Z = 1.04) and in the microstructure of the resulting polynorbornene. Consequently, addn. of acid and protonation of the living catalyst attached to the polymer chain during the polymn. reaction allows fine-tuning the E/Z ratio of the resulting polynorbornene.

The metathesis activity of Grubbs' catalyst 1 was studied in the presence of N-donor ligands (1-methylimidazole [MIM], 4-(N,N-dimethylamino)pyridine [DMAP], pyridine, and 1-octylimidazole [OIM]). Ring opening metathesis polymn. (ROMP) reactions of cyclooctene (COE), bulk-ROMP reactions of COE and norbornadiene (NBD), and ring closing metathesis (RCM) reactions of di-Et diallylmalonate (DEDAM) were conducted contg. various equiv. of N-donor with respect to catalyst. ROMP reactions could be stopped using MIM (1-5 equiv) and DMAP (2-5 equiv), and slowed with pyridine (1-5 equiv) by factors >100, in benzene soln. for 24 h. The stopped reactions could be initiated with excess phosphoric acid (H3PO4), and the reactions proceeded faster than with uninhibited Grubbs' catalyst in the first 4 min after reactivation. Thereafter, the reaction proceeded at the same rate as the reaction with the uninhibited catalyst. ROMP reactions in neat COE and NBD could be inhibited for 72 h using 2 equiv of MIM, DMAP, or OIM and activated with H3PO4 to give polymer gels within minutes or less. RCM reactions could be completely inhibited with MIM (1-5 equiv), but upon treatment with H3PO4, the reaction would proceed at a fraction of the initial rate accomplished by uninhibited Grubbs' catalyst 1. A structural study of the inhibited species showed that MIM and DMAP completely or partially transform catalyst 1 into the hexacoordinate species 5a or 5b producing free PCy3, which addnl. acts as an inhibitor for the ROMP reaction. Upon reactivation, the PCy3 is protonated along the N-donor ligand; however, over the period of 5 min, the phosphine was found to coordinate back to the ruthenium catalyst. Therefore, the reaction slows to the same polymn. rate as the reaction using the uninhibited catalyst at this point. Complexes 5a and 5b were isolated, characterized, and employed in ROMP and RCM expts. where they exhibited low catalytic activity.

Efficient light and thermal activated metathesis reactions of tetra-substituted olefins were obtained by the S-chelated ruthenium pre-catalyst Tol-SCF3. Herein, the design and synthesis of an electron rich, sulfoxide-chelated, ruthenium benzylidene (I) (Mes = mesityl) is demonstrated. In contrast to previously reported sulfoxide-chelated ruthenium benzylidenes, this complex is more stable in a cis-dichloro conformation, and is thus latent in typical olefin metathesis reactions. The complex was characterized by NMR, UV-Vis and X-ray spectroscopy, alongside DFT computations. The latent pre-catalyst could be activated thermally and, depending on the solvent, also by UV-C or visible light. In addn., an original 'thermo-chromatic' orthogonal sequence was developed, further improved by the use of a thioether chelated complex, where a divergent two-step synthesis can lead to a dihydrofuran or a dihydropyran depending only on the order by which the different stimuli, heat or light, are applied.

Highly thermally stable N-aryl, N-alkyl N-heterocyclic carbene (NHC) ruthenium catalysts were designed and synthesized for latent olefin metathesis. Ruthenium imidazolidinylidene 2-isopropoxybenzylidene complexes [(1-Ar-3-tBu-C3H4N2)Cl2Ru:CHC6H4OiPr-2-κO] (1, 2, Ar = 2-tBuC6H4, 2,6-iPr2C6H3) and their iodide analogs [(1-Ar-3-tBu-C3H4N2)I2Ru:CHC6H4OiPr-2-κO] (9, 10, same Ar) were prepd. and tested; while in 1-hexene dimerization, yielding 5-decene, the complexes 1, 2 showed their latent character, being active at 85° and non-active at 25°, in ROMP of norbornene derivs., 2,3-COXCOC7H8 [X = NCH2Ph, N(CH2)4CH(CO2H)NHFmoc, CH2CH2OH, O] only the iodides 9, 10 were latent, giving ROM-polymers at 85°. These catalysts showed excellent latent behavior toward metathesis reactions, whereby the complexes were inactive at ambient temp. and initiated at elevated temps., a challenging property to achieve with second-generation catalysts. A sterically hindered N-tert-Bu substituent on the NHC ligand of the ruthenium complex was found to induce latent behavior toward cross-metathesis reactions, and exchange of the chloride ligands for iodide ligands was necessary to attain latent behavior during ring-opening metathesis polymn. (ROMP). Iodide-based catalysts showed no reactivity toward ROMP of norbornene-derived monomers at 25 °C and upon heating to 85 °C gave complete conversion of monomer to polymer in less than 2 h. All of the complexes were very stable to air, moisture, and elevated temps. up to at least 90 °C and exhibited a long catalyst lifetime in soln. at elevated temps.

Prepn., substrate scope, and activity of a previously reported mech. activated metathesis catalyst were studied. Scission of the catalyst under ultrasound irradn. was followed by GPC, which showed a 1st-order scission rate const. of 0.011 min-1. The resulting active species has catalytic reactivity in ring closing metathesis (RCM) of various (un)hindered substrates. Further studies of the active species showed that it was not influenced by radicals formed during ultrasound and that the most effective method to increase its lifetime was an increase in the substrate concn. In ring-opening metathesis polymn. (ROMP), the lifetime of the active species is several hours, in contrast to the short lifetimes found in RCM. ROMP expts. also showed that all of the latent precatalyst broken leads to active catalyst species.

Homogeneously catalyzed reactions can be "switched on" by activating latent catalysts. Usually, activation is brought about by heat or an external chem. agent. However, activation of homogeneous catalysts with a mech. trigger has not been demonstrated. Here, we introduce a general method to activate latent catalysts by mech. breaking bonds between a metal and one of its ligands. We have found that silver(i) complexes of polymer-functionalized N-heterocyclic carbenes, which are latent organo catalysts, catalyze a transesterification reaction when exposed to ultrasound in soln. Furthermore, ultrasonic activation of a ruthenium biscarbene complex with appended polymer chains results in catalysis of olefin metathesis reactions. In each case, the catalytic activity results from ligand dissocn., brought about by transfer of mech. forces from the polymeric substituents to the coordination bond. Mechanochem. catalyst activation has potential applications in transduction and amplification of mech. signals, and mech. initiated polymns. hold promise as a novel repair mechanism in self-healing materials.

IR anal. of 4 revealed that the oxidn. of the ferrocene moiety in 2 significantly reduced the electron-donating ability of the N-heterocyclic carbene ligand, causing change of Tolman electronic parameter (TEP) by 9 cm-1. The oxidn. of 5 with ferrocenium salt [Fe(η5-C5H4COMe)Cp][BF4] as well as the subsequent redn. of the corresponding product [5][BF4] with decamethylferrocene (Fc*) each proceeded in greater than 95% yield. Moessbauer, UV/Vis and EPR spectroscopy anal. confirmed that [5][BF4] contained a ferrocenium species, indicating that the iron center was selectively oxidized over the ruthenium center. Complexes 5 and [5][BF4] were found to catalyze the ring-closing metathesis (RCM) of di-Et diallylmalonate with obsd. pseudo-first-order rate consts. (kobs) of 3.1·10-4 and 1.2·10-5 s-1, resp. By adding suitable oxidants or reductants over the course of a RCM reaction, complex 5 was switched between different states of catalytic activity. A second-generation N-heterocyclic carbene that featured a 1',2',3',4',5'- pentamethylferrocenyl (Fc') moiety, 1-Fc'-3-mesitylimidazol-2-ylidene (L10, 10) was also prepd. and metal complexes contg. this ligand were found to undergo iron-centered oxidns. at lower potentials than analogous complexes supported by 2 (0.30-0.36 V vs. 0.56-0.62 V, resp.). Redox switching expts. using [Ru(L10)Cl2(:CH-o-O-iPrC6H4)] revealed that greater than 94% of the initial catalytic activity was restored after an oxidn.-redn. cycle.

A redox-switchable ligand, N,N'-dimethyldiaminocarbene[3]ferrocenophane (5), was synthesized and incorporated into a series of Ir- and Ru-based complexes. Electrochem. and spectroscopic analyses of (5)Ir(CO)2Cl (15) revealed that 5 displayed a Tolman electronic parameter value of 2050 cm-1 in the neutral state and 2061 cm-1 upon oxidn. Moreover, inspection of x-ray crystallog. data recorded for (5)Ir(cis,cis-1,5-cyclooctadiene)Cl (13) revealed that 5 was sterically less bulky (%VBur = 28.4) than other known diaminocarbene[3]ferrocenophanes, which facilitated the synthesis of (5)(PPh3)Cl2Ru(3-phenylindenylid-1-ene) (18). Complex 18 exhibited quasi-reversible electrochem. processes at 0.79 and 0.98 V relative to SCE, which were assigned to the Fe and Ru centers in the complex, resp., based on UV-vis and electron pair resonance spectroscopic measurements. Adding 2,3-dichloro-5,6-dicyanoquinone over the course of a ring-opening metathesis polymn. of cis,cis-1,5-cyclooctadiene catalyzed by 18 ([monomer]0/[18]0 = 2500) reduced the corresponding rate const. of the reaction by over an order of magnitude (pre-oxidn.: kobs = 0.045 s-1; post-oxidn.: kobs = 0.0012 s-1). Subsequent redn. of the oxidized species using decamethylferrocene restored catalytic activity (post-redn.: kobs = up to 0.016 s-1, depending on when the reductant was added). The difference in the polymn. rates was attributed to the relative donating ability of the redox-active ligand (i.e., strongly donating 5 vs. weakly donating 5+) which ultimately governed the activity displayed by the corresponding catalyst.

A review. The most important means for tuning and improving a catalyst's properties is the delicate exchange of the ligand shell around the central metal atom. Perhaps for no other organometallic-catalyzed reaction is this statement more valid than for ruthenium-based olefin metathesis. Indeed, even the simple exchange of an oxygen atom for a sulfur atom in a chelated ruthenium benzylidene about a decade ago resulted in the development of extremely stable, photoactive catalysts. This Account presents our perspective on the development of dormant olefin metathesis catalysts that can be activated by external stimuli and, more specifically, the use of light as an attractive inducing agent. The insight gained from a deeper understanding of the properties of cis-dichlororuthenium benzylidenes opened the doorway for the systematic development of new and efficient light-activated olefin metathesis catalysts and catalytic chromatic-orthogonal synthetic schemes. Following this, ways to disrupt the ligand-to-metal bond to accelerate the isomerization process that produced the active precatalyst were actively pursued. Thus, we summarize herein the original thermal activation expts. and how they brought about the discoveries of photoactivation in the sulfur-chelated benzylidene family of catalysts. The specific wavelengths of light that were used to dissoc. the sulfur-ruthenium bond allowed us to develop noncommutative catalytic chromatic-orthogonal processes and to combine other photochem. reactions with photoinduced olefin metathesis, including using external light-absorbing mols. as "sunscreens" to achieve novel selectivities. Alteration of the ligand sphere, including modifications of the N-heterocyclic carbene (NHC) ligand and the introduction of cyclic alkyl amino carbene (CAAC) ligands, produced more efficient light-induced activity and special chem. selectivity. The use of electron-rich sulfoxides and, more prominently, phosphites as the agents that induce latency widened the spectrum of light-induced olefin metathesis reactions even further by expanding the colors of light that may now be used to activate the catalysts, which can be used in applications such as stereolithog. and 3D printing of tough metathesis-derived polymers.

The ligand shell that surrounds an active metal center has a paramount effect on its reactivity and properties. In this work, the photoswitchable nature of phosphite olefin metathesis precatalysts and the robustness of cyclic alkyl amino carbene (CAAC) ligands are combined. Also, the synthesis, characterization, and photoactivity of two ruthenium indenylidene complexes bearing a CAAC/phosphite ligand system are reported. Exposure to 405 nm light efficiently activates the precatalysts and promotes a wide range of olefin metathesis reactions. Moreover, the catalysts display formidable latency at ambient temps., even with the highly reactive dicyclopentadiene and its derivs., allowing the prepn. of stable monomer-catalyst formulations with a long pot life. In addn., the chemoselectivity of CAAC catalysts is preserved, preventing olefin migration reactions at elevated temps. and allowing efficient recycling for multiple reaction cycles under air.

A review. Olefin metathesis is one of the most important methods to form carbon-carbon double bonds and has found many applications in industry and academia. The ability to initiate the reaction using external stimulus such as light, with high spatial and temporal resoln. is highly advantageous and provides creative novel opportunities in org. syntheses and material sciences. This review article covers recent advances in light-activated olefin metathesis reactions from the development of novel complexes that can be initiated photochem. to recently reported applications of photoinduced olefin metathesis, as well as the bright newly emerging field of photoredox-mediated metal-free ROMP.

A review. Light activation is a most desirable property for catalysis control. Among many catalytic processes that may be activated by light, olefin metathesis stands out as both academically motivating and practically useful. Starting from early tungsten heterogeneous photoinitiated metathesis, up to modern ruthenium methods based on complex photoisomerization or indirect photoactivation, this survey of the relevant literature summarizes past and present developments in the use of light to expedite olefin ring-closing, ring-opening polymn. and cross-metathesis reactions.

Olefin metathesis is now one of the most efficient ways to create new carbon-carbon bonds. While most efforts focused on the development of ever-more efficient catalysts, a particular attention has recently been devoted to developing latent metathesis catalysts, inactive species that need an external stimulus to become active. This furnishes an increased control over the reaction which is crucial for applications in materials science. Here, we report our work on the development of a new system to achieve visible-light-controlled metathesis by merging olefin metathesis and photoredox catalysis. The combination of a ruthenium metathesis catalyst bearing two N-heterocyclic carbenes with an oxidizing pyrylium photocatalyst affords excellent temporal and spatial resoln. using only visible light as stimulus. Applications of this system in synthesis, as well as in polymer patterning and photolithog. with spatially resolved ring-opening metathesis polymn., are described.

A dithienylethene-functionalized N-heterocyclic carbene-Ru(II) complex was synthesized and found to undergo a reversible photoisomerization which influenced its intrinsic catalytic activity. UV-induced ring-closure enhanced the rate of ring-closing metathesis reactions (kclosed/kopened = 1.4-1.7) and attenuated the rate of ring-opening metathesis polymns. (kclosed/kopened = 0.56-0.66). Visible light irradn. promoted cycloreversion and restored the initial activity. The ability to switch between the isomeric states of the catalyst was also utilized to modulate the rate of ongoing olefin metathesis reactions via photoirradn. A review. The photoisomerization of azobenzene has been known for almost 75 years but only recently has this process been widely applied to biol. systems. The central challenge of how to productively couple the isomerization process to a large functional change in a biomol. has been met in a no. of instances and it appears that effective photocontrol of a large variety of biomols. may be possible. This crit. review summarizes key properties of azobenzene that enable its use as a photoswitch in biol. systems and describes strategies for using azobenzene photoswitches to drive functional changes in peptides, proteins, nucleic acids, lipids, and carbohydrates (192 refs.).

A review. Azobenzene undergoes trans cis isomerization when irradiated with light tuned to an appropriate wavelength. The reverse cis trans isomerization can be driven by light or occurs thermally in the dark. Azobenzene's photochromatic properties make it an ideal component of numerous mol. devices and functional materials. Despite the abundance of application-driven research, azobenzene photochem. and the isomerization mechanism remain topics of study. Addnl. substituents on the azobenzene ring system change the spectroscopic properties and isomerization mechanism. This crit. review details the studies completed to date on the 3 main classes of azobenzene derivs. Understanding the differences in photochem., which originate from substitution, is imperative in exploiting azobenzene in the desired applications.

Azobenzene is a switchable compd. that exhibits reversible trans-cis photoisomerization. Photoresponsive polymers have been prepd. by incorporating azobenzene groups into polymers. Most of the reported azobenzene-contg. polymers (azopolymers) have only one azobenzene group in the repeat unit of the polymers (mono-azopolymers). To improve photoresponsiveness, multi-azobenzene groups have been covalently or non-covalently introduced into the repeat units of azopolymers (multi-azopolymers). In this Perspective, we introduce photoresponsive multi-azopolymers. We summarize the prepn. of such polymers and highlight their potential applications in photoactuation, photo-patterning, and photoinduced birefringence. The innovative potential, open questions, and remaining challenges in this field are also discussed.

A review. Mol. photoswitches are a class of chem. structures that can readily isomerize between distinct geometries upon irradn. with light. Mol. photoswitches are utilized to control protein structure and function with temporal and spatial precision. In this review, we summarize the recent progress in the development of azobenzene-based mol. photoswitches and their applications in the photocontrol of protein structure and function. For clarity of discussion, we divide the known photoswitchable proteins into different categories: protein motifs, ion channels, receptors, and enzymes. Basic approaches and considerations for the structure-guided design of photoswitchable ligands are discussed. The applications and limitations of current photoswitches are also discussed.

Polymer 2, when perfectly threo-disyndiotactic, adopts a "barb"-shaped geometry with its cyclic malonate pendants sticking out alternately up and down along the rigid main chain. Under appropriate conditions, strich-2 regularly self-assembles, not only in the solid state but also in soln., into nanofibers that eventually give rise to phys. gelation of halogenated solvents such as CH2Cl2. In sharp contrast, a ref. polymer 2 that is rich in threo-diisotactic sequences (itrich-2), which likely adopts a helical geometry, has poor self-assembly capability in soln. and neither forms nanofibers nor induces phys. gelation of CH2Cl2.

A review. Catalysis is key to the effective and efficient transformation of readily available building blocks into high value functional mols. and materials. For many years research in this field has largely focused on the invention of new catalysts and the optimization of their performance to achieve high conversions and/or selectivities. However, inspired by Nature, chemists are beginning to turn their attention to the development of catalysts whose activity in different chem. processes can be switched by an external stimulus. Potential applications include using the states of multiple switchable catalysts to control sequences of transformations, producing different products from a pool of building blocks according to the order and type of stimuli applied. Here we outline the state-of-art in artificial switchable catalysis, classifying systems according to the trigger used to achieve control over the catalytic activity and stereochem. or other structural outcomes of the reaction.

Patterning functional materials is a central challenge across many fields of science. The ability to lithog. fabricate micro- and nanostructures has been one of the most impactful technol. breakthroughs of the last century. In part due to the complexity of the chem. processes in photoresists, there is a limited variety of materials that can currently be patterned by photolithog. We report a neg. tone photoresist using a photoactivated olefin metathesis catalyst, which can be quickly prepd. in a one-pot synthesis from com. available starting materials. The resist is based on a ruthenium vinyl ether complex, widely regarded as inactive toward olefin metathesis. The combination of this photoactivated catalyst with the fidelity and functional group tolerance of ruthenium-mediated olefin metathesis enables a host of new possibilities for photopatterned materials.

The amidine/alc. system, which originally belonged to CO2 binding org. liqs., served as an efficient CO2-responsive catalyst/initiator system for lactide polymn. Chemoselective block copolymn. between polylactide and polycarbonate was further explored by opposite gas-controlled amidine and another CrIII catalyst, where an immortal strategy was developed for conjugated alternation of inverse polymns. on different active species and permits many potential applications.

The reaction of meta- and para-bromomethylene-azobenzenes with 1-methyl-imidazole yields the resp. meta-/para-functionalized azobenzenes tagged with an imidazolium group. Similar reactions of ortho- and para-bromo-azobenzene with imidazole and successive quaternation with benzyl bromide give the analogs, with an imidazolium group in ortho/para substituted azobenzenes. With the exception of the ortho deriv., all imidazolium salts could be transformed into their resp. silver(I) complexes by reaction with Ag2O. Transmetalation of these silver(I) complexes with (Me2S)AuCl gives the azobenzene-contg. complexes (NHC)AuCl. Two of these formed crystals suitable for x-ray diffraction, which revealed the typical linear coordination geometry of the NHC-Au-Cl moiety. All gold complexes feature E/Z photo-isomerization upon irradn. with UV light. The thermal back reaction to the E-isomers is relatively slow and comparable to that of other azobenzene compds.

A review. We have known of azobenzene for over 150 years, the past 80 of which have seen the study and application of its photochromism. Azobenzene derivs. are now considered archetypical mol. switches, and their stability and reliability make them amenable to many fields of modern chem., materials science, biol. and photopharmacol. When developing a photoswitch for a given application, a common approach is to tune the properties of an azobenzene. It is also possible to instead use heteroaryl azo dyes - motifs that are less popular even though their diversity offers distinct features. Despite the first discoveries of switching behavior in heteroaryl azos and azobenzenes being coincident, the former have only recently begun to attract attention. This Review describes how the versatile and multifaceted characteristics of these scaffolds make them serious alternatives to azobenzene derivs. in mol. photoactuation. Heteroaryl azo photoswitches arguably deserve more consideration, and our survey of these systems includes challenges to their successful deployment.

A review. Catalysis is key to the effective and efficient transformation of readily available building blocks into high value functional mols. and materials. For many years research in this field has largely focused on the invention of new catalysts and the optimization of their performance to achieve high conversions and/or selectivities. However, inspired by Nature, chemists are beginning to turn their attention to the development of catalysts whose activity in different chem. processes can be switched by an external stimulus. Potential applications include using the states of multiple switchable catalysts to control sequences of transformations, producing different products from a pool of building blocks according to the order and type of stimuli applied. Here we outline the state-of-art in artificial switchable catalysis, classifying systems according to the trigger used to achieve control over the catalytic activity and stereochem. or other structural outcomes of the reaction.

A review. Synthetic polymer chem. endeavors to imitate the spatial and temporal control exhibited within biol. systems to obtain well-defined polymeric materials with unique structures, properties, and applications. This is often approached through the development of dynamic catalyst (or initiator) systems that use external stimuli to elicit discrete, site specific transformations that impact the polymn. Herein, we highlight developments in polymns. that are modulated by external stimuli, with particular focus on those systems that enable notable changes in kinetics, monomer selectivity, polymer architecture, or tacticity. Examples of external stimuli include chem. oxidants or reductants, light, applied voltage, and mech. force.

It is well-recognized that N-heterocyclic carbene (NHC) ligands have provided a new dimension to the design of homogeneous catalysts. Part of the success of this type of ligands resides in the limitless access to a variety of topologies with tuned electronic properties, but also in the ability of a family of NHCs that are able to adapt their properties to the specific requirements of individual catalytic transformations. The term "smart" is used here to refer to switchable, multifunctional, adaptable, or tunable ligands and, in general, to all those ligands that are able to modify their steric or electronic properties to fulfill the requirements of a defined catalytic reaction. The purpose of this review is to comprehensively describe all types of smart NHC ligands by focusing attention on the catalytically relevant ligand-based reactivity.

A review. While significant progress has clearly been made,future efforts should be directed toward achieving more sophisticated control over the switchable characteristics of a system. For instance, the synthesis of complex materials with precisely tailored microstructures may be possible through the development of polymn. catalyst capable of two discrete switching mechanisms induced by orthogonal external stimuli. Alternatively, the development of novel switchable polymn. catalysts contg. multiple distinct catalytic center that can be selectively switched on and off independent of each other could also lead to an enhanced level of control over polymer architecture (e.g., tacticity, compn., topol., etc.). Nevertheless, the nascent field of switchable polymns. represents a useful alternative to conventional methods and is expected to facilitate the realization of new polymeric materials that are currently challenging or impossible to synthesize using known techniques.

A review is given. Responsive systems have recently gained much interest in the scientific community in attempts to mimic dynamic functions in biol. systems. One of the fascinating potential applications of responsive systems lies in catalysis. Inspired by nature, novel responsive catalytic systems have been built that show analogy with allosteric regulation of enzymes. The design of responsive catalytic systems allows control of catalytic activity and selectivity. Here, advances in the field over the last 4 decades are discussed and a comparison is made amongst the dynamic responsive systems based on the principles underlying their catalytic mechanisms. The catalyst systems are sorted according to the triggers used to achieve control of the catalytic activity and the distinct catalytic reactions illustrated.

The metathesis activity of Grubbs' catalyst 1 was studied in the presence of N-donor ligands (1-methylimidazole [MIM], 4-(N,N-dimethylamino)pyridine [DMAP], pyridine, and 1-octylimidazole [OIM]). Ring opening metathesis polymn. (ROMP) reactions of cyclooctene (COE), bulk-ROMP reactions of COE and norbornadiene (NBD), and ring closing metathesis (RCM) reactions of di-Et diallylmalonate (DEDAM) were conducted contg. various equiv. of N-donor with respect to catalyst. ROMP reactions could be stopped using MIM (1-5 equiv) and DMAP (2-5 equiv), and slowed with pyridine (1-5 equiv) by factors >100, in benzene soln. for 24 h. The stopped reactions could be initiated with excess phosphoric acid (H3PO4), and the reactions proceeded faster than with uninhibited Grubbs' catalyst in the first 4 min after reactivation. Thereafter, the reaction proceeded at the same rate as the reaction with the uninhibited catalyst. ROMP reactions in neat COE and NBD could be inhibited for 72 h using 2 equiv of MIM, DMAP, or OIM and activated with H3PO4 to give polymer gels within minutes or less. RCM reactions could be completely inhibited with MIM (1-5 equiv), but upon treatment with H3PO4, the reaction would proceed at a fraction of the initial rate accomplished by uninhibited Grubbs' catalyst 1. A structural study of the inhibited species showed that MIM and DMAP completely or partially transform catalyst 1 into the hexacoordinate species 5a or 5b producing free PCy3, which addnl. acts as an inhibitor for the ROMP reaction. Upon reactivation, the PCy3 is protonated along the N-donor ligand; however, over the period of 5 min, the phosphine was found to coordinate back to the ruthenium catalyst. Therefore, the reaction slows to the same polymn. rate as the reaction using the uninhibited catalyst at this point. Complexes 5a and 5b were isolated, characterized, and employed in ROMP and RCM expts. where they exhibited low catalytic activity.

A ruthenium carbene complex bearing azobenzene functionality is reported. The complex exists in the form of two isomers differing by the size of the chelate ring. Both isomers were isolated by applying kinetic or thermodn. control during the synthesis and characterized by X-ray diffraction anal. The isomerization of the complex was studied by UV/Vis spectroscopy. The stable isomer was tested as a catalyst in olefin metathesis. The complex was activated at about 100 °C to promote ring-closing and ring-opening polymn. metathesis reactions. The activation took place also at room temp. under middle UV radiation.

Herein, the design and synthesis of an electron rich, sulfoxide-chelated, ruthenium benzylidene (I) (Mes = mesityl) is demonstrated. In contrast to previously reported sulfoxide-chelated ruthenium benzylidenes, this complex is more stable in a cis-dichloro conformation, and is thus latent in typical olefin metathesis reactions. The complex was characterized by NMR, UV-Vis and X-ray spectroscopy, alongside DFT computations. The latent pre-catalyst could be activated thermally and, depending on the solvent, also by UV-C or visible light. In addn., an original 'thermo-chromatic' orthogonal sequence was developed, further improved by the use of a thioether chelated complex, where a divergent two-step synthesis can lead to a dihydrofuran or a dihydropyran depending only on the order by which the different stimuli, heat or light, are applied.

Highly thermally stable N-aryl, N-alkyl N-heterocyclic carbene (NHC) ruthenium catalysts were designed and synthesized for latent olefin metathesis. Ruthenium imidazolidinylidene 2-isopropoxybenzylidene complexes [(1-Ar-3-tBu-C3H4N2)Cl2Ru:CHC6H4OiPr-2-κO] (1, 2, Ar = 2-tBuC6H4, 2,6-iPr2C6H3) and their iodide analogs [(1-Ar-3-tBu-C3H4N2)I2Ru:CHC6H4OiPr-2-κO] (9, 10, same Ar) were prepd. and tested; while in 1-hexene dimerization, yielding 5-decene, the complexes 1, 2 showed their latent character, being active at 85° and non-active at 25°, in ROMP of norbornene derivs., 2,3-COXCOC7H8 [X = NCH2Ph, N(CH2)4CH(CO2H)NHFmoc, CH2CH2OH, O] only the iodides 9, 10 were latent, giving ROM-polymers at 85°. These catalysts showed excellent latent behavior toward metathesis reactions, whereby the complexes were inactive at ambient temp. and initiated at elevated temps., a challenging property to achieve with second-generation catalysts. A sterically hindered N-tert-Bu substituent on the NHC ligand of the ruthenium complex was found to induce latent behavior toward cross-metathesis reactions, and exchange of the chloride ligands for iodide ligands was necessary to attain latent behavior during ring-opening metathesis polymn. (ROMP). Iodide-based catalysts showed no reactivity toward ROMP of norbornene-derived monomers at 25 °C and upon heating to 85 °C gave complete conversion of monomer to polymer in less than 2 h. All of the complexes were very stable to air, moisture, and elevated temps. up to at least 90 °C and exhibited a long catalyst lifetime in soln. at elevated temps.

Prepn., substrate scope, and activity of a previously reported mech. activated metathesis catalyst were studied. Scission of the catalyst under ultrasound irradn. was followed by GPC, which showed a 1st-order scission rate const. of 0.011 min-1. The resulting active species has catalytic reactivity in ring closing metathesis (RCM) of various (un)hindered substrates. Further studies of the active species showed that it was not influenced by radicals formed during ultrasound and that the most effective method to increase its lifetime was an increase in the substrate concn. In ring-opening metathesis polymn. (ROMP), the lifetime of the active species is several hours, in contrast to the short lifetimes found in RCM. ROMP expts. also showed that all of the latent precatalyst broken leads to active catalyst species.

Homogeneously catalyzed reactions can be "switched on" by activating latent catalysts. Usually, activation is brought about by heat or an external chem. agent. However, activation of homogeneous catalysts with a mech. trigger has not been demonstrated. Here, we introduce a general method to activate latent catalysts by mech. breaking bonds between a metal and one of its ligands. We have found that silver(i) complexes of polymer-functionalized N-heterocyclic carbenes, which are latent organo catalysts, catalyze a transesterification reaction when exposed to ultrasound in soln. Furthermore, ultrasonic activation of a ruthenium biscarbene complex with appended polymer chains results in catalysis of olefin metathesis reactions. In each case, the catalytic activity results from ligand dissocn., brought about by transfer of mech. forces from the polymeric substituents to the coordination bond. Mechanochem. catalyst activation has potential applications in transduction and amplification of mech. signals, and mech. initiated polymns. hold promise as a novel repair mechanism in self-healing materials.

High yielding syntheses of ferrocenyl-substituted NHC, 1-(ferrocenylmethyl)-3-mesitylimidazolium iodide (1) and 1-(ferrocenylmethyl)-3-mesitylimidazol-2-ylidene (2) were developed. Complexation of 2 (L2) to [{Ir(cod)Cl}2] (cod = cis,cis-1,5-cyclooctadiene) or [Ru(PCy3)Cl2(:CH-o-O-iPrC6H4)] (Cy = cyclohexyl) afforded [Ir(L2)(cod)Cl] (3) and Hoveyda-type complex [Ru(L2)Cl2(:CH-o-O-iPrC6H4)] (5), resp. Dicarbonyl complex [Ir(L2)(CO)2Cl] (4) was obtained by bubbling carbon monoxide through a soln. of 3 in CH2Cl2. Spectroelectrochem. IR anal. of 4 revealed that the oxidn. of the ferrocene moiety in 2 significantly reduced the electron-donating ability of the N-heterocyclic carbene ligand, causing change of Tolman electronic parameter (TEP) by 9 cm-1. The oxidn. of 5 with ferrocenium salt [Fe(η5-C5H4COMe)Cp][BF4] as well as the subsequent redn. of the corresponding product [5][BF4] with decamethylferrocene (Fc*) each proceeded in greater than 95% yield. Moessbauer, UV/Vis and EPR spectroscopy anal. confirmed that [5][BF4] contained a ferrocenium species, indicating that the iron center was selectively oxidized over the ruthenium center. Complexes 5 and [5][BF4] were found to catalyze the ring-closing metathesis (RCM) of di-Et diallylmalonate with obsd. pseudo-first-order rate consts. (kobs) of 3.1·10-4 and 1.2·10-5 s-1, resp. By adding suitable oxidants or reductants over the course of a RCM reaction, complex 5 was switched between different states of catalytic activity. A second-generation N-heterocyclic carbene that featured a 1',2',3',4',5'- pentamethylferrocenyl (Fc') moiety, 1-Fc'-3-mesitylimidazol-2-ylidene (L10, 10) was also prepd. and metal complexes contg. this ligand were found to undergo iron-centered oxidns. at lower potentials than analogous complexes supported by 2 (0.30-0.36 V vs. 0.56-0.62 V, resp.). Redox switching expts. using [Ru(L10)Cl2(:CH-o-O-iPrC6H4)] revealed that greater than 94% of the initial catalytic activity was restored after an oxidn.-redn. cycle.

A Ru(II) complex ligated to a quinone-annulated N-heterocyclic carbene (NHC) was synthesized as a redox-active analog of the Hoveyda-Grubbs II generation catalyst. The complex exhibited a single reversible redn. with a E1/2 of -0.63 V (vs. SCE), and was successfully reduced and then oxidized with high fidelity using chem. reagents. While the catalyst facilitated a range of ring-closing metathesis (RCM) reactions in its neutral state, its activity was inhibited upon the introduction of a suitable reducing reagent. A series of d. functional theory calcns. revealed that the differences in catalytic activity may be attributed to the stronger donating ability of the reduced NHC ligand which stabilized a ruthenacyclobutane intermediate and thus suppressed the rate-detg. retro-[2 + 2] cycloaddn. step of the underlying RCM mechanism.

Eight N-Hoveyda-type complexes were synthesized in yields of 67-92% through reaction of [RuCl2(NHC)(Ind)(py)] [NHC = 1,3-bis(2,4,6-trimethylphenylimidazolin)-2-ylidene (SIMes) or 1,3-bis(2,6-diisopropylphenylimidazolin)-2-ylidene (SIPr), Ind = 3-phenylindenylid-1-ene, py = pyridine] (I) with 1- or 1,2-substituted ferrocene compds. with vinyl and amine or imine substituents. The redox potentials of the resp. complexes were detd.; in all complexes an iron-centered oxidn. reaction occurs at potentials close to E = 0.5 V. The crystal structures of the reduced and of the resp. oxidized Hoveyda-type complexes were detd. and show that the oxidn. of the ferrocene unit has little effect on the ruthenium environment. Two of the eight complexes (i.e., those prepd. from I and the ferrocene complex having vinyl and mesitylimino groups) were found to be switchable catalysts, in that the reduced form is inactive in the ring-opening metathesis polymn. of cis-cyclooctene (COE), whereas the oxidized complexes produce polyCOE. The other complexes are not switchable catalysts and are either inactive or active in both reduced and oxidized states.

A redox-switchable ligand, N,N'-dimethyldiaminocarbene[3]ferrocenophane (5), was synthesized and incorporated into a series of Ir- and Ru-based complexes. Electrochem. and spectroscopic analyses of (5)Ir(CO)2Cl (15) revealed that 5 displayed a Tolman electronic parameter value of 2050 cm-1 in the neutral state and 2061 cm-1 upon oxidn. Moreover, inspection of x-ray crystallog. data recorded for (5)Ir(cis,cis-1,5-cyclooctadiene)Cl (13) revealed that 5 was sterically less bulky (%VBur = 28.4) than other known diaminocarbene[3]ferrocenophanes, which facilitated the synthesis of (5)(PPh3)Cl2Ru(3-phenylindenylid-1-ene) (18). Complex 18 exhibited quasi-reversible electrochem. processes at 0.79 and 0.98 V relative to SCE, which were assigned to the Fe and Ru centers in the complex, resp., based on UV-vis and electron pair resonance spectroscopic measurements. Adding 2,3-dichloro-5,6-dicyanoquinone over the course of a ring-opening metathesis polymn. of cis,cis-1,5-cyclooctadiene catalyzed by 18 ([monomer]0/[18]0 = 2500) reduced the corresponding rate const. of the reaction by over an order of magnitude (pre-oxidn.: kobs = 0.045 s-1; post-oxidn.: kobs = 0.0012 s-1). Subsequent redn. of the oxidized species using decamethylferrocene restored catalytic activity (post-redn.: kobs = up to 0.016 s-1, depending on when the reductant was added). The difference in the polymn. rates was attributed to the relative donating ability of the redox-active ligand (i.e., strongly donating 5 vs. weakly donating 5+) which ultimately governed the activity displayed by the corresponding catalyst.

A review. The most important means for tuning and improving a catalyst's properties is the delicate exchange of the ligand shell around the central metal atom. Perhaps for no other organometallic-catalyzed reaction is this statement more valid than for ruthenium-based olefin metathesis. Indeed, even the simple exchange of an oxygen atom for a sulfur atom in a chelated ruthenium benzylidene about a decade ago resulted in the development of extremely stable, photoactive catalysts. This Account presents our perspective on the development of dormant olefin metathesis catalysts that can be activated by external stimuli and, more specifically, the use of light as an attractive inducing agent. The insight gained from a deeper understanding of the properties of cis-dichlororuthenium benzylidenes opened the doorway for the systematic development of new and efficient light-activated olefin metathesis catalysts and catalytic chromatic-orthogonal synthetic schemes. Following this, ways to disrupt the ligand-to-metal bond to accelerate the isomerization process that produced the active precatalyst were actively pursued. Thus, we summarize herein the original thermal activation expts. and how they brought about the discoveries of photoactivation in the sulfur-chelated benzylidene family of catalysts. The specific wavelengths of light that were used to dissoc. the sulfur-ruthenium bond allowed us to develop noncommutative catalytic chromatic-orthogonal processes and to combine other photochem. reactions with photoinduced olefin metathesis, including using external light-absorbing mols. as "sunscreens" to achieve novel selectivities. Alteration of the ligand sphere, including modifications of the N-heterocyclic carbene (NHC) ligand and the introduction of cyclic alkyl amino carbene (CAAC) ligands, produced more efficient light-induced activity and special chem. selectivity. The use of electron-rich sulfoxides and, more prominently, phosphites as the agents that induce latency widened the spectrum of light-induced olefin metathesis reactions even further by expanding the colors of light that may now be used to activate the catalysts, which can be used in applications such as stereolithog. and 3D printing of tough metathesis-derived polymers.

The ligand shell that surrounds an active metal center has a paramount effect on its reactivity and properties. In this work, the photoswitchable nature of phosphite olefin metathesis precatalysts and the robustness of cyclic alkyl amino carbene (CAAC) ligands are combined. Also, the synthesis, characterization, and photoactivity of two ruthenium indenylidene complexes bearing a CAAC/phosphite ligand system are reported. Exposure to 405 nm light efficiently activates the precatalysts and promotes a wide range of olefin metathesis reactions. Moreover, the catalysts display formidable latency at ambient temps., even with the highly reactive dicyclopentadiene and its derivs., allowing the prepn. of stable monomer-catalyst formulations with a long pot life. In addn., the chemoselectivity of CAAC catalysts is preserved, preventing olefin migration reactions at elevated temps. and allowing efficient recycling for multiple reaction cycles under air.

Olefin metathesis is now one of the most efficient ways to create new carbon-carbon bonds. While most efforts focused on the development of ever-more efficient catalysts, a particular attention has recently been devoted to developing latent metathesis catalysts, inactive species that need an external stimulus to become active. This furnishes an increased control over the reaction which is crucial for applications in materials science. Here, we report our work on the development of a new system to achieve visible-light-controlled metathesis by merging olefin metathesis and photoredox catalysis. The combination of a ruthenium metathesis catalyst bearing two N-heterocyclic carbenes with an oxidizing pyrylium photocatalyst affords excellent temporal and spatial resoln. using only visible light as stimulus. Applications of this system in synthesis, as well as in polymer patterning and photolithog. with spatially resolved ring-opening metathesis polymn., are described.

A dithienylethene-functionalized N-heterocyclic carbene-Ru(II) complex was synthesized and found to undergo a reversible photoisomerization which influenced its intrinsic catalytic activity. UV-induced ring-closure enhanced the rate of ring-closing metathesis reactions (kclosed/kopened = 1.4-1.7) and attenuated the rate of ring-opening metathesis polymns. (kclosed/kopened = 0.56-0.66). Visible light irradn. promoted cycloreversion and restored the initial activity. The ability to switch between the isomeric states of the catalyst was also utilized to modulate the rate of ongoing olefin metathesis reactions via photoirradn. A computational investigation revealed how steric and electronic effects sep. influence the transition states adopted by each form of the catalyst and afforded activation energies that were in agreement with the relative reaction rate consts. detd. by expt.

A review. The photoisomerization of azobenzene has been known for almost 75 years but only recently has this process been widely applied to biol. systems. The central challenge of how to productively couple the isomerization process to a large functional change in a biomol. has been met in a no. of instances and it appears that effective photocontrol of a large variety of biomols. may be possible. This crit. review summarizes key properties of azobenzene that enable its use as a photoswitch in biol. systems and describes strategies for using azobenzene photoswitches to drive functional changes in peptides, proteins, nucleic acids, lipids, and carbohydrates (192 refs.).

A review. Azobenzene undergoes trans cis isomerization when irradiated with light tuned to an appropriate wavelength. The reverse cis trans isomerization can be driven by light or occurs thermally in the dark. Azobenzene's photochromatic properties make it an ideal component of numerous mol. devices and functional materials. Despite the abundance of application-driven research, azobenzene photochem. and the isomerization mechanism remain topics of study. Addnl. substituents on the azobenzene ring system change the spectroscopic properties and isomerization mechanism. This crit. review details the studies completed to date on the 3 main classes of azobenzene derivs. Understanding the differences in photochem., which originate from substitution, is imperative in exploiting azobenzene in the desired applications.

Azobenzene is a switchable compd. that exhibits reversible trans-cis photoisomerization. Photoresponsive polymers have been prepd. by incorporating azobenzene groups into polymers. Most of the reported azobenzene-contg. polymers (azopolymers) have only one azobenzene group in the repeat unit of the polymers (mono-azopolymers). To improve photoresponsiveness, multi-azobenzene groups have been covalently or non-covalently introduced into the repeat units of azopolymers (multi-azopolymers). In this Perspective, we introduce photoresponsive multi-azopolymers. We summarize the prepn. of such polymers and highlight their potential applications in photoactuation, photo-patterning, and photoinduced birefringence. The innovative potential, open questions, and remaining challenges in this field are also discussed.

A review. Mol. photoswitches are a class of chem. structures that can readily isomerize between distinct geometries upon irradn. with light. Mol. photoswitches are utilized to control protein structure and function with temporal and spatial precision. In this review, we summarize the recent progress in the development of azobenzene-based mol. photoswitches and their applications in the photocontrol of protein structure and function. For clarity of discussion, we divide the known photoswitchable proteins into different categories: protein motifs, ion channels, receptors, and enzymes. Basic approaches and considerations for the structure-guided design of photoswitchable ligands are discussed. The applications and limitations of current photoswitches are also discussed.

Eight new ruthenium(II) half-sandwich complexes contg. azobenzene-appended pyridine (1), bipyridine (2-5) and phosphine (6 and 7) ligands have been synthesized and fully characterized. UV-vis spectroscopic studies showed that the trans-to-cis photoisomerization was strongly inhibited upon coordination to the metal center in azopyridine-derived ligands 1 and 2, but it remained efficient in azobenzene-appended bipyridine (3-5) and phosphine (6 and 7) ligands. The complexes were tested as precatalysts for photo-controlled hydrogen generation by hydrolytic decompn. of ammonia-borane (AB). In situ irradn. of the reaction mixts. of compds. [Ru(p-Cym)(6)Cl]Cl and [Ru(p-Cym)(7)Cl]Cl induced a clear change in the catalytic reaction rate, serving as a proof of concept for light-controlled hydrogen generation.

A review. Catalysis is key to the effective and efficient transformation of readily available building blocks into high value functional mols. and materials. For many years research in this field has largely focused on the invention of new catalysts and the optimization of their performance to achieve high conversions and/or selectivities. However, inspired by Nature, chemists are beginning to turn their attention to the development of catalysts whose activity in different chem. processes can be switched by an external stimulus. Potential applications include using the states of multiple switchable catalysts to control sequences of transformations, producing different products from a pool of building blocks according to the order and type of stimuli applied. Here we outline the state-of-art in artificial switchable catalysis, classifying systems according to the trigger used to achieve control over the catalytic activity and stereochem. or other structural outcomes of the reaction.

A review. This review describes the state of the art in photoswitchable organometallic catalysis, underlining the importance of ligand design. The implementation of spatio-temporal control on known catalytic processes has been appealing to several researchers for a long time. Even though the area is still in its infancy, the diversity of the existing examples shows that there are plenty possibilities in terms of the photochromic actuator of choice, and on the expected effect of the photochem. transformation on the catalytic process. The pioneering examples discussed here are, in many cases, just basic models far from efficient. However, they suffice to envisage the magnitude of the space that remains unexplored, letting us foresee that exciting innovations are awaiting.

Patterning functional materials is a central challenge across many fields of science. The ability to lithog. fabricate micro- and nanostructures has been one of the most impactful technol. breakthroughs of the last century. In part due to the complexity of the chem. processes in photoresists, there is a limited variety of materials that can currently be patterned by photolithog. We report a neg. tone photoresist using a photoactivated olefin metathesis catalyst, which can be quickly prepd. in a one-pot synthesis from com. available starting materials. The resist is based on a ruthenium vinyl ether complex, widely regarded as inactive toward olefin metathesis. The combination of this photoactivated catalyst with the fidelity and functional group tolerance of ruthenium-mediated olefin metathesis enables a host of new possibilities for photopatterned materials.

The reaction of meta- and para-bromomethylene-azobenzenes with 1-methyl-imidazole yields the resp. meta-/para-functionalized azobenzenes tagged with an imidazolium group. Similar reactions of ortho- and para-bromo-azobenzene with imidazole and successive quaternation with benzyl bromide give the analogs, with an imidazolium group in ortho/para substituted azobenzenes. With the exception of the ortho deriv., all imidazolium salts could be transformed into their resp. silver(I) complexes by reaction with Ag2O. Transmetalation of these silver(I) complexes with (Me2S)AuCl gives the azobenzene-contg. complexes (NHC)AuCl. Two of these formed crystals suitable for x-ray diffraction, which revealed the typical linear coordination geometry of the NHC-Au-Cl moiety. All gold complexes feature E/Z photo-isomerization upon irradn. with UV light. The thermal back reaction to the E-isomers is relatively slow and comparable to that of other azobenzene compds.

A review. We have known of azobenzene for over 150 years, the past 80 of which have seen the study and application of its photochromism. Azobenzene derivs. are now considered archetypical mol. switches, and their stability and reliability make them amenable to many fields of modern chem., materials science, biol. and photopharmacol. When developing a photoswitch for a given application, a common approach is to tune the properties of an azobenzene. It is also possible to instead use heteroaryl azo dyes - motifs that are less popular even though their diversity offers distinct features. Despite the first discoveries of switching behavior in heteroaryl azos and azobenzenes being coincident, the former have only recently begun to attract attention. This Review describes how the versatile and multifaceted characteristics of these scaffolds make them serious alternatives to azobenzene derivs. in mol. photoactuation. Heteroaryl azo photoswitches arguably deserve more consideration, and our survey of these systems includes challenges to their successful deployment.
